title: How Plastic Straws Affect the Ocean and Sea Turtles - Green Matters
body: Plastic straws are one of the top 10 items found every year during Ocean Conservancy's International Coastal Cleanup. Plastic is not biodegradable — instead, the material eventually breaks down into tiny particles known as microplastics that are 5 millimeters or smaller in length, making them difficult to clean or filter from the ocean.

- GreenMatters (2019-08-14): Plastic straws have a significant impact on the environment and sea animals, despite only accounting for a small percentage of ocean plastic. The material eventually breaks down into microplastics, affecting underwater ecosystems and leading to the deaths of sea animals. Fishing gear, particularly abandoned equipment, contributes to a larger portion of ocean plastic. Additionally, microplastics have been found in seafood, posing potential risks to human health. The article also highlights the power of individuals in reversing the issue, suggesting strategies to reduce ocean plastic, such as using plastic straw alternatives and supporting accessibility for individuals who require plastic straws.
